docs.lead_paragraph: The Ford Motor Company told retired salaried employees in the United States yesterday that they would pay more of their health care costs starting in June as the company tries to return to profitability. The retirees, who do not pay a monthly premium now, may pay $5 to $150 a month depending on the number of people covered, their Medicare status and the coverage plan they select, a spokeswoman said. The change involves about 50,000 retirees and spouses, Ford said. Retired workers represented by the United Auto Workers are not affected.

headline.main: SOME FORD RETIREES WILL PAY MORE FOR MEDICAL CARE

docs.abstract: Ford Motor Co tells retired salaried employees in US that they will pay more of their health care costs starting in June; retirees, who do not pay monthly premium now, may pay $5 to $150 per month depending on number of people covered, their Medicare status and coverage plan they select; retired workers represented by United Auto Workers are not affected (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Centocor, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, has been providing doctors with marketing materials that describe how they can make extra money by prescribing a new drug, a practice that health care fraud experts say may be illegal. Some doctors have recently raised concerns about Centocor's marketing of the new drug, Remicade, an expensive treatment for rheumatoid arthritis.

headline.main: Methods Used For Marketing Arthritis Drug Are Under Fire

docs.abstract: Centocor, subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, has been providing doctors with marketing materials that describe how they can make extra money by prescribing expensive rheumatoid arthritis drug called Remicade, practice that health care fraud experts say may be illegal; document once available to doctors on Centocor's Web site stated that included worksheet where physicians could calculate their 'estimated revenue per patient' from prescribing drug; worksheet stated 'revenue' was primarily difference between what Medicare pays doctors for drug and lower amount that Centocor charged doctors for drug; drug is one of few rheumatoid arthritis treatments that Medicare covers; Centocor says company does not talk about profitability and how physicians can make money; Dr Paul April says other doctors have told him that Centocor representatives invited them to meeting where they could learn about how they could profit from Remicade (M)
docs.snippet: Centocor, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, has been providing doctors with marketing materials that describe how they can make extra money by prescribing a new drug, a practice that health care fraud experts say may be illegal.    Some doctors have...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ronnie Musgrove has vetoed the state's Medicaid budget, saying lawmakers failed to fill a $120 million gap for the federal-state health insurance program that serves more than 600,000 elderly, poor and disabled people. The governor, a Democrat, warned on Monday that the cuts could force 13,000 state residents out of nursing homes and cut off many drug prescriptions, a contention dismissed as a scare tactic by leaders of the Democratic-controlled Legislature. Lawmakers were confident that they would override the veto.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Veto On Medicaid Budget

docs.abstract: Gov Ronnie Musgrove vetoes Mississippi's Medicaid budget, saying lawmakers failed to fill $120 million gap for federal-state health insurance program that serves more than 600,000 elderly, poor and disabled people (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Decades after American companies largely stopped using asbestos, a wave of asbestos-related lawsuits is again flooding the nation's courts. The suits, once filed mainly against shipbuilders, makers of asbestos and companies in a few other industries, now touch thousands of companies. In the last two years, they have forced at least 18 companies, with more than 100,000 employees, into bankruptcy protection.

headline.main: A Surge in Asbestos Suits, Many by Healthy Plaintiffs

docs.abstract: Wave of asbestos-related lawsuits is again flooding US courts, decades after American companies generally stopped using asbestos, and many of thousands of companies targeted did not make asbestos or use it heavily in their products; table; graph; exposure to asbestos has plunged since 1970's and very few new plaintiffs have serious injuries, as even their lawyers acknowledge, but at least 90,000 new claims were filed last year alone; companies that have lost multimillion-dollar judgments since last fall include Dow, Halliburton and 3M; Viacom reported 106,000 claims related to one-time ownership of Westinghouse; Congress will get bill that would delay lawsuits by healthy plaintiffs (M)
docs.snippet: Decades after American companies largely stopped using asbestos, a wave of asbestos-related lawsuits is again flooding the nation's courts.    The suits, once filed mainly against shipbuilders, makers of asbestos and companies in a few other...

docs.lead_paragraph: After a short speech on Monday night he invited questions, and it came as no surprise, he said later, that no one in the audience mentioned Wen Ho Lee, nobody asked whether China had succeeded in buying nuclear secrets, and Bill Clinton's name never came up. That is the way it usually goes, Bill Richardson said, completing another day in his campaign for governor of New Mexico. The state has too many other problems, he maintained, for voters to worry about ancient political history, even if he played a prominent role in it.

headline.main: A Candidate Tries to Keep His Troubles Behind Him

docs.abstract: Former Energy Sec Bill Richardson campaigns for governor of New Mexico, where being only Democrat in race gives him clear path to November election, in which he will face victor in June 4 Republican primary; Republican contenders are John A Sanchez and Robert M Burpo, state lawmakers, and Walter D Bradley, lieutenant governor; Richardson is highly popular, but also carries some political baggage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven large drug companies plan to announce today that they have joined to provide low-income elderly people with a card that they say will provide discounts of 20 percent or more on dozens of prescription medicines. Another drug maker, Merck & Company, said yesterday that it would be making it easier for low-income people of all ages to obtain its medicines free.

headline.main: 7 Companies Join to Offer Discounts on Drugs to the Elderly

docs.abstract: Seven large drug companies plan to announce that they have joined to provide low-income elderly people with card that they say will provide discounts of 20 percent or more on dozens of prescription medicines; Merck & Co says it will be making it easier for low-income people of all ages to obtain its medicines free; Johnson & Johnson is joining Abbott Laboratories, Aventis, Britsol-Myers Squibb, AstraZeneca, GlaxoSmithKline and Novartis in offering program called Together Rx Card (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''V.A. Health Care Strained by Big Wave of Enrollees'' (front page, April 6):

headline.main: V.A. Health Care: Easing the Costs

docs.abstract: Letter by Richard J Santos, national commander of American Legion, says Medicare should be allowed to reimburse Veterans Affairs Department for treatment of Medicare-eligible veterans (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''V.A. Health Care Strained by Big Wave of Enrollees'' (front page, April 6):

docs.lead_paragraph: Though most government officials and cancer experts urge middle-aged and elderly women to have mammograms every year, it is becoming harder to get them in many parts of the country. Nationwide, 9,451 mammography centers were accredited as of late February -- 422 fewer than a year before, including declines of 51 in California, 24 in New York, 19 in New Jersey and 12 in Connecticut. Analysts said some of the lost services might have been maintained in nearby centers or clinics that merged, but other clinics had simply closed.

headline.main: Mammogram Centers Facing Rising Costs and Low Reimbursements

docs.abstract: Article on decline in number of accredited mammography centers in US, which is leading to longer wait times for appointments at same time number of women at risk for breast cancer is growing; insurers are under pressure to persuade younger women to have tests but radiologists say payments for mammograms by Medicare and managed care insurers have lagged behind rising costs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An Internet-based system being introduced today will allow doctors to send prescriptions directly to a pharmacy's computer from a hand-held or desk-top computer, wireless telephone or text pager. Using the system, being offered by the Giant supermarket and pharmacy chain and the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, pharmacists can send back information over a two-way network about potentially harmful drug reactions as well as a patient's insurance coverage.

headline.main: So Much for Doctors' Bad Handwriting on Drug Prescriptions

docs.abstract: Internet-based system being offered by Giant supermarket and pharmacy chain and National Association of Chain Drug Stores will allow doctors to send prescriptions directly to pharmacy's computer from hand-held or desk-top computer, wireless telephone or text pager; Giant Food Inc, unit of Royal Ahold, is testing new system at six pharmacies and plans to install it next month in 154 pharmacies; system was developed by physicians at InstantDX; it will be available to 30,000 doctors who use physicians' office software of NDCHealth Corp; doctors will pay monthly subscription fee of about $30 for services, and pharmacies will pay transaction fee (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald Berry, the head of biostatistics at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, has a Ph.D. in his field and long years of expertise in designing and interpreting results of clinical trials. Dr. David Freedman, a statistics professor at the University of California at Berkeley, has similar credentials.

headline.main: Different Conclusion From the Same Study

docs.abstract: Article on different views by M D Anderson Cancer Center statistician Dr Donald Berry and University of California statistician Dr David Freedman over major mammography study conducted by Health Insurance Plan; two agree that study, which found higher breast cancer death rate among women who did not have mammograms, was flawed because those who already had breast cancer diagnosis were dropped; disagree over whether results show mammography is significant screening tool; photos (M)
